article.headline: Mitt Romney says fellow Senate Republican Ron Johnsonâs probe into Biden son is not a legitimate function of government
article.body: WASHINGTON (AP) â Republican Sen. Mitt Romney is sharply criticizing an investigation by his own party into Democratic presidential nominee Joe Bidenâs son, saying itâs ânot the legitimate role of governmentâ to try and damage political opponents. GOP Sen. Ron Johnson, chairman of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, has said the committee will issue a report before the Nov. 3 election on Hunter Bidenâs activities in Ukraine. Johnson, a close ally of President Donald Trump, is leading the investigation into Burisma, a gas company in Ukraine that paid Hunter Biden to serve as a board member while Joe Biden was vice president to President Barack Obama. He has been quoted as saying he thought his investigation âwould certainly help Donald Trump win re-election.â See:Wisconsin Republican Ron Johnson on defensive over probe of Biden and Ukraine in wake of intelligence assessment about ongoing Russian election interference Most Republican senators have been on board with Johnsonâs inquiry. But Romney, a frequent Trump critic, has repeatedly made clear he has concerns about politicizing the committeeâs work. “ âObviously, it is the province of campaigns and political partiesâ opposition research, the media, to carry out political endeavors, to learn about or dust up oneâs opponent. But itâs not the legitimate role of government or Congress, or for taxpayer expense to be used in an effort to damage political opponents.â ” â Sen. Mitt Romney The Utah lawmaker, who was the 2012 Republican presidential candidate, had his strongest words yet for what he called the âBiden-Burismaâ investigation at a committee meeting Wednesday, saying that the inquiry from the âoutset had the earmarks of a political exercise.â Romney added: âObviously, it is the province of campaigns and political partiesâ opposition research, the media, to carry out political endeavors, to learn about or dust up oneâs opponent. But itâs not the legitimate role of government or Congress, or for taxpayer expense to be used in an effort to damage political opponents.â From the archives (March 2020):Romney says he will vote to back fellow Republican Ron Johnsonâs push to investigate Burisma and Bidens Johnson did not respond to the comments during the meeting. But he had earlier withdrawn from the meetingâs agenda a vote to authorize an additional subpoena, a move that Romney praised. Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee Chairman Ron Johnson of Wisconsin speaks during a Wednesday meeting of the committee. Associated Press A committee aide said that the subpoena was withdrawn because the witness, Bridget Brink, the U.S. ambassador to Slovakia, had agreed to testify voluntarily. The aide was not authorized to publicly discuss committee work taking place in private and spoke on condition of anonymity. In a statement responding to Romneyâs comments, Johnson spokesman Ben Voelkel said âthe American people have the right to knowâ the facts of the investigation. âThis is Congress,â Voelkel said. âEverything here has implications for politics and elections. The Committee is expressly authorized to investigate conflicts of interest, and its investigation into Burisma and U.S.-Ukraine policy began well before the Democratic nominee for President had been decided.â There is no evidence of wrongdoing by the Bidens, and Hunter Biden has denied using his influence with his father to aid Burisma. In a statement, Joe Biden spokesman Andrew Bates called the investigation âdisgraceful.â NBC News reported early Thursday that the Johnson-led committee would hear later in the day from a former State Department official who has reportedly told colleagues that Burisma had no bearing on U.S. policy toward Ukraine. “ Johnson objected as Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and Sen. Ron Wyden offered a resolution calling for âthe cessation of any Senate investigation or activity that allows Congress to act as a conduit for Russian disinformation.â ” Senate Democrats have strongly objected to the inquiry and have charged that Johnson could be amplifying Russian propaganda to hurt Biden. After Wednesdayâs meeting, Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer of New York and Sen. Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, offered a resolution calling for âthe cessation of any Senate investigation or activity that allows Congress to act as a conduit for Russian disinformation.â Johnson himself came to the floor to object, preventing the measureâs passage. He denied that any Russian disinformation was part of the investigation, calling the Democratsâ resolution âfalse chargesâ and âwild claims against me.â Republicans coming to Trumpâs defense during and after last yearâs impeachment trial have encouraged investigations of Hunter Bidenâs activities, questioning whether his highly paid job created a conflict of interest for Joe Biden as the elder Biden worked on Ukraine policy in the Obama administration. Trump has frequently mentioned Hunter Bidenâs activities during his re-election campaign. The presidentâs efforts to have Ukraine investigate Hunter Bidenâs role were also at the heart of last yearâs House impeachment investigation. Trump asked Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate the Bidens on a July phone call that was later revealed by a whistleblowerâs complaint. The House impeached Trump in December for pressuring the Ukrainian government on investigations while withholding military aid to the country. The Senate acquitted him in February. Romney was the only Republican to vote for one of the articles of impeachment.
